awd_titl_txt: Proposal for the Operation of Regional Class Research Vessel #3 in the Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea, and southwestern Atlantic Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Operator Selection for NSF Regional Class Research Vessel #3.   A research vessel in the Gulf of Mexico will help to support scientifically important work in geological, geophysical and biological processes.   Studying  "societally" relevant topics such as sea level rise, changing weather and climate patterns, and the implications for scientifically and commercially important ecosystems and species.

 The Gulf of Mexico is also an economic hotspot for fisheries, energy, tourism, etc. Louisiana and Mississippi are both EPSCOR states, and operating this vessel is its own kind of economic stimulation. The consortium is committed to improving diversity and inclusivity in the southern U.S.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview 

This project was to form the Gulf - Caribbean Oceanographic Consortium (GCOC) with the purpose of serving as the Operating Institution (OI) of the third Regional Class Research Vessel (RCRV), R/V Gilbert R. Mason, currently being built by the National Science Foundation (NSF). When completed, R/V Mason’s scientific home port will be the University of Southern Mississippi’s (USM) Roger F. Wicker Center for Ocean Enterprise, located in Gulfport, MS. This facility began construction in 2019, and opened for operations in 2023. A goal of this project was to successfully open the facility to support the future ship. R/V Mason will also be supported by maintenance facilities provided by the Louisianna Universities Marine Consortium (LUMCON) still under construction in Houma, LA.  The GCOC is established to support leadership, management, and decision making for ship operations, research support and consortium vision. Both USM and LUMCON have provided staff to support the construction phase of R/V Mason, which continues as of the conclusion of this award. When vessel construction is complete, and the vessel moves to the transition to operations phase, and ultimately operations, the GCOC will manage and maintain facilities, a talented ship and marine technician team, and develop best practices for facilitating scientific research. The GCOC operating area will focus on the Gulf of Mexico, western Atlantic and Caribbean and will maximize the effective use of the future  NSF-owned RCRV.    

Intellectual Merit 

R/V Mason will support advancement of ocean science research broadly, and enable scientists to address priority research questions presented in both the Sea Change report by the National Academy of Sciences (2015), and the forthcoming second Decadal Survey of Ocean Sciences, to be published in early 2025. The operation of an RCRV from the northern Gulf of Mexico will provide a required resource to meet science’s and society’s need for research about the ocean. The work of the GCOC will support current and future scientists through tools, infrastructure, access and qualified personnel. The GCOC will work to maintain that R/V Mason’s capabilities align with and are poised to accomplish NSF and other Federal agency missions. R/V Mason will be a platform for transformative regional, national and international research that address societally relevant topics long into the future.  

Broader Impacts 

The motto of R/V Mason is “Equal Access to the Sea”. This motto is inspired by the life work of the ship’s namesake, the late Dr. Gilbert R. Mason, physician and civil rights activist in Mississippi. This motto is a commitment by the GCOC to support societally relevant broader impact work spanning education, outreach, and engagement of communities and partners in science. These activities align with the Mission of the GCOC and draw from successful programs at USM and LUMCON. Through the ship, the GCOC will develop opportunities for students, professionals, and the public to connect with marine scientists and their works. Ultimately, R/V Mason will be an entry point to grow the ocean science workforce and a means to inject the valuable perspectives of people across the Gulf of Mexico region into solving problems and finding opportunities in ocean science.
